text_paragraphs: Information Note on the Court’s case-law No.
Length of three sets of civil proceedings: violation

[This summary is extracted from the Court’s official reports (Series A or Reports of Judgments and Decisions). Its formatting and structure may therefore differ from the Case-Law Information Note summaries.]
A.	Periods to be taken into consideration
Proceedings against Dieppe Health Insurance Office (CPAM): nine years and seven months.
Proceedings against Union des assurances de Paris (UAP): eight years and nearly eight months.
Proceedings against Dieppe Family Allowances Office (CAF): eight years, eight months and two weeks.
B.	Reasonableness of length of proceedings
(b)	Conduct of the parties and of the judicial authorities
Reasonableness of length of proceedings before social-security appeal tribunals assessed in same way as before ordinary civil courts.
Applicant's conduct not beyond reproach - most of the delays nevertheless attributable to conduct of the administrative and judicial authorities.
(b)	Conduct of the parties and of the judicial authorities
Applicant's conduct not beyond reproach - authorities responsible for some of the delays.
(c)	What was at stake for applicant in proceedings
Applicant's situation and what was at stake for him in proceedings had called for special expedition.
(b)	Conduct of the parties and of the judicial authorities
Applicant's conduct not beyond reproach - most of the delays nevertheless attributable to conduct of the administrative and judicial authorities.
A.	Damage: claim for pecuniary damage dismissed.  Non-pecuniary damage assessed on equitable basis.
Conclusion: respondent State ordered to pay applicant a specified sum (unanimously).
B.	Recommendation sought by applicant: court had no jurisdiction to issue order to Contracting State.
C.	Costs and expenses: applicant's claim allowed.
Conclusion: respondent State ordered to pay specified sums to applicant (unanimously).

This summary by the Registry does not bind the Court.
